fields.descriptive_line: Theatrical ensemble of coat and two waistcoats, worn by Henry Irving as Vanderdecken, in W.G. Wills and Percy Fitzgerald's 'Vanderdecken'. 1878, at the Lyceum under Mrs Bateman's management.
fields.physical_description:
[waistcoat] Waistcoat of sage-green silk, with deep brown fur collar. Decorated at the chest with couched thread in blues, greens, browns and gold. Seven buttons and buttonholes down centre front. Two patch pockets, mismatched fabric and pocket on at mismatched angles, front panels. Back cream cotton waist to hem and brown cotton shoulder to waist. Two buckles and straps above and below waist level. Lined in cream cotton.
[waistcoat] Black wool waistcoat, double breasted and fastening with two rows of self covered buttons. Section of white cotton collar tacked into neckline of front, left, panel. Lined in biege twilled cotton. Back panels made from dark brown glazed cotton with strap of same fastened by metal buckle. Front panels sewn with peacock feathers .
[coat] Black wool coat covered by black crepe gauze, over rows of braid woven with black faceted glass beads. Panels of vibrant fuchsia silk on left and right inside collar, seemingly to fold down as 'revers' when worn. At each cuff there is a single, round, plastic, button and 3 small hanging points, all beaded and covered with gauze, as with rest of coat. Large single button on right front panel, waist level and corresponding buttonhole on left front panel at hip level. Coat loose fitting and voluminous, reaching to about mid-calf when worn.There is an intentional slit at the rear of the coat.
fields.dimensions:
[waistcoat] Length: 50.5 cm, Width: 36.5 cm Across shoulders
[coat] Length: 119 cm From back of collar to hem
fields.materials_techniques:
[waistcoat] Silk, appliqued, fur
[waistcoat] Fabric with peacock feathers
fields.public_access_description:
Henry Irving (1838-1905) wore this costume in the title role of Vanderdecken by Percy Fitzgerald (1834-1925) and William Gorman Wills (1828–1891).  Fitzgerald’s inspiration was Wagner’s 1843  opera The Flying Dutchman, the tale of a ship captained by a man cursed with eternal life.   Although Irving’s production in 1878 was praised for its picturesque qualities, and his appearance as Vanderdecken was recorded in a painting by Stanley Lathbury and a plaster bust by Edward Onslow Ford, the play was thought too wordy and lacking in action.  

The coat is particularly interesting as crepe gauze has been tacked over faceted beads to allow Irving to lurk in the shadows at the back of the stage until lighting was shone directly on him. At which point the beads which would shine through this gauze and reveal him to the audience.

Irving became a professional actor in 1856, and learned his trade in regional theatres until 1866, when he came to London.  He joined the Lyceum Theatre company under the management of H. L. Bateman in 1871, winning great acclaim that year for his psychologically developed characterisation of the guilt-ridden inn-keeper Mathias in Leopold Lewis’s melodrama The Bells.  He took on the responsibilities of ‘actor-manager’ in 1878 when he assumed the management of the Lyceum, and remained there until 1902, enjoying star status with his leading lady Ellen Terry (1847-1928).   Irving produced a diverse range of old and new plays at the Lyceum, including Shakespeare, historical drama, and literary adaptations.  His tireless work to elevate the status of the theatrical profession was rewarded in 1895 when he became the first actor ever to receive a knighthood for services to the Theatre.

Irving specialised in spectacularly staged productions with large casts of performers. He commissioned designers and composers to create appropriate scenery, costume and incidental music, played by a full orchestra.  Although electric lighting was available from the 1880s, Irving preferred the softer effects of gas, with lime light to focus attention at key points in the play.  Irving toured complete productions outside London, taking the full company, scenery and costumes throughout the United Kingdom and across the United States and Canada.   The development of the railway system made his the first generation able to achieve this level of touring productions.
fields.bibliography: Holmes, Martin. <u>Stage Costumes and Accessories in the London Museum</u>. London : HMSO, 1968. Catalogue entry 78.
